@scott_lew_is Kelvin, a protocol where action within the protocol is inhibited the more it is used. As the protocol use grows above absolute zero it slows. Reduced use cools the programmatic brakes and invites participation. Same when usage is high but stable, allowing set point to rise.

@JESSCATE93 The final neurology page may be a consumable that someone might benefit from. The page has a lineage of historical edits (list of authors) and hyperlinks (list of pages containing their own list of authors). To "tip" neurology is to route payment to all authors to a certain depth

I'm starting to get the feeling that the number of people working on tying value transfer to the process of information creation is very large. 

There also seems to be a whole swath of mechanisms to achieve this being explored. 

Duplicated effort or a blossoming garden? ‚è≥üå±

@guiltygyoza As the latency from ideation to reception and assimilation drops, the number of people that can work on a problem will rise. Perhaps we are leaving the Information Age to enter a Collaborative Age akin to a hive mind.

Where fearful protection and patenting of ideas will fade.

@guiltygyoza Heartbreakingly to breathtakingly, in the span of a generation. When viewed through the lens of millennia, perhaps even eons, the friction in memetic transmission of ideas is a transient hurdle that we seem to have cleared, but are yet to land. Doubling time changes will be epic.

@nicksdjohnson The device could have no screen and could instead render the image with ASCII in terminal using duckyscript when plugged into a computer. The private key is enclaved until something is broken on the device. Then when plugged in it generates a EIP-712 QR code ASCII in terminal.

@nicksdjohnson You could make an "openDime NFT" where the device has a low power display, a procedural svg and a breakaway to start the claim process - screen shows image then changes to QR . Small button cell or passive power. You could "trade" them off chain and inspect to verify unclaimed.
@martriay Interesting that password auth will be replaced by key-based auth only when people have some tangible reason to coordinate around proper key management.

CleanserDAO: Resource heavy DAO tasked to trigger cascading liquidations. To clear the air for individuals to take long positions. Membership seen on the individual level as a contribution for public good.

@brendan_dharma I think that value proposition for ether goes way beyond "coolness". A myriad of factors may drive desire. At the time of quantification of an amount to use, the units should be shifted to make them readable to a human eye.

Does it feel cooler to earn 5000 cents/hour?

@brendan_dharma Redefining a unit also ruins so much existing documentation and communication ground work. 

If people use ether in the future it will be because it has practical value for some concrete purpose. Like monetary policy or convenience. The language will follow.

@brendan_dharma Redefining a unit to be a convenient number for a specific use is short sighted. What about a future where services are payed in extremely small units at high frequency?

Service cost quoted at nETH/s "nanoether per second" allows for service costs to be compared.

@brendan_dharma Just normalise a specific SI prefix as needed.

We do it for many other things: ML dams, L milk, uL

uETH / microether 

It may be tempting to think that it is "too hard" to learn or that it takes too long to say, preventing adoption. Look at kilograms.

@BastardWhiskey @888Mooncat @ohr_nft @bganpunks @NFTX_ @berkozdemir Thanks! I love to scroll through them seeing how different features are represented. Often I find that while no single feature is obvious, the GACTAN has the same vibe as the BGAN

@BastardWhiskey @888Mooncat @ohr_nft @bganpunks @NFTX_ @berkozdemir So it's possible that the results of the first pass through have more beardy structures than the second. First passed are visible with the ipfs suffix '_first.jpg'

A beard-naive model might see a beard and liken it to some other feature, such as a shadow. https://t.co/JILBZ0a8nY

@BastardWhiskey @888Mooncat @ohr_nft @bganpunks @NFTX_ @berkozdemir The bastards are used as the input to a generator trained in human faces. The generator takes the bastard and tweaks it until it appears "passable" as a face. 

I passed the image through two generators, the first to make the face front-on, the second to super-resolution/celebify

@BastardWhiskey @888Mooncat @ohr_nft @bganpunks @NFTX_ @berkozdemir Good observation. I suspect that the answer lies in that the database of faces used to train the generator was low on beards. Some stubble here and there. I wonder if a full beard can be found!

It's not limited to money-for-writing

It is securing identity into the structure of a piece. Identity that persists. Some future DAO may admit the authors as honorary members or advisors.

For a manifesto that made no money, but that was culturally significant. Credibly neutral

If there is a main trunk with traction and you see a great idea on another branch, you can copy/rephrase their work and "hat tip" that commit. This adds your address, and theirs, to the main trunk. Rewarding creation and curation.

What do you think? üé®

The incentive is to write things that other writers write upon. With the knowledge that an audience may reward some version that you may or may not be part of. 

Plagiarism is culturally enforced. The timestamp and signature illuminate branches with crude attempts.

One or more articles may emerge, variants in the theme - perhaps aimed at different audiences. Translations, too.

A publisher may buy the right to publish. 

1) pick a suitable version. 
2) send a single sum to the contract, which routes payment, equally, to all in that lineage.

Another author can choose to edit the second version, adding their address. Or, build on the single-address original.

The hashes are logged in an L2 to preserve ordering.

One thousand contributors swarm to build and aggregate around a main trunk. Typos fixes locked in amber.

Idea for an architecture for collectively written works.

An author writes a piece, and publishes git-style, with an standardised header containing a license and eth address.

Another author rewrites a section, adds their address and publishes the new hash.

No approvals needed

@ComplicatedIsOK @FroggyFrogster @epolynya Flavour 5: [your custom flavour here, hand crafted for your application]

If anyone has specific architectures that they would like to see materialised, let me know! Models, drafts, sketches, diagrams, musings all welcome

@ComplicatedIsOK @FroggyFrogster @epolynya Not quite - there will always be a signature check.

More that: accounts can now come in different flavours. 

Flavour 1: simple single owner
Flavour 2: multiple owners
Flavour 3: trader special (only profitable trades)
Flavour 4: shadow (can de-link deposits and withdrawls)

GAN idea: width invariant ASCII art

The gan is trained to produce some image, but the width of the text varies cycle to cycle. 

So it must learn to create patterns that when wrapped in different ways form different features.

Robust ASCII kernels for a mobile era.

So the premise is that the artist contribution is:

- important (warrants eth as DA layer)
- ordered (sequencing required)
- not composable (may be consumed off chain)

The tree of pending blocks in the contract gives a freedom for creative reorgs for redirection.

Probably exists in some form, and am interested in anyone's thoughts on terminology.

Shadowchain + log

ShadowLog?

I have a fun idea that it could be used for. I think it will be really cheap to run (not compared to L2s) and could be an interactive piece. Artists "mine" the tip

You submit a new block as tx data, along with a pointer to an existing chain tip/branch, the contract checks some validity condition on the data and then walks the state forward. Emits an event.

Archive node + log gets tx data = chain data. Contract defines canonical chain head

I have a design variant on PosterChain (H/T @DennisonBertram) that involves a chain that lives in transaction space, but where the smart contract maintains a small mempool of blocks and enforces state transition. Like a shadowchain that lives inside the archive nodes tx record.

I think that there is a flaw where people won't know if they are going to make the quota when they send the transaction

So you could end up with many transactions still, but they are all reverts. Then they have to try again later, doubling the spam

@nicksdjohnson @jeffscottward This is a fair point.

The basefee is a proxy for network usage, so it requires some careful design based on desired network basefee conditions. In this respect it is inferior to the auction, which allows the market to decide the magic numbers

@nicksdjohnson @jeffscottward Yes it's just a super minimal mechanism raise price (can donate). But it serves to spread the load out over a longer time because you can tweak the mint window.  If the fee is okay at BF 40, high at BF 60 and unaffordable at BF 80, then users can still pay 70 for other things

@nicksdjohnson @jeffscottward Tokens remain mintable while the base fee is high. 

Could try other formulae (x * basefee **5)
